g.text: Theoretical Physics Division, Department of Physics, Chemistry and Biology (FIM),
Materials Modeling and Development Laboratory, National University of Science and Technology (NUST) “MISIS”,
The lead-free halide double perovskite class of materials offers a promising venue for resolving issues
related to toxicity of Pb and long-termstability of the lead-containing halide perovskites. We present a first-
principles study of the lattice vibrations in Cs
, the prototypical compound in this class and show
that the lattice dynamics of Cs
is highly anharmonic, largely in regards to tilting of AgBr
octahedra. Using an energy- and temperature-dependent phonon spectral function, we then show
how the experimentally observed cubic-to-tetragonal phase transformation is caused by the collapse of a
soft phonon branch. We finally reveal that the softness and anharmonicity of Cs
thermal conductivity, unexpected of high-symmetry cubic structures.
Novel complex materials envisioned for future energy
technologies are often highly anharmonic; i.e., their
atomic vibrations strongly deviate from those described
by a set of uncoupled harmonic oscillators, which makes
ticular, lead halide perovskites, which have emerged as
one of the most promising and intensively studied class of
an organic cation such as methylammonium or formami-
F, Cl, Br, or I, is highly complex, with
large observed differences between local and average
frequency, often unstable, octahedral tilting modes and
particular, related to the rotational dynamics of the organic
. This complex atomic motion has a large
impact on electronic properties through a strong electron-
influential on the optoelectronic performance of these
The so-called lead-free halide double perovskites
replaced by pairs of mono- and trivalent cations such as
, are envisioned to solve crucial issues
of the single lead halide perovskites relating to poor long-
term stability and the presence of toxic Pb. Unfortunately,
they typically have band gaps that are larger than optimal
chemical space within this class of materials that can be
explored in attempts to tune crucial properties. The elec-
tron-phonon coupling appears to be strong in these systems
, which makes a thorough characterization of the
nature of the anharmonic lattice vibrations highly desirable
Generally, the tendency toward octahedral tilting insta-
bilities of the aristotype cubic perovskite structure can be
understood in terms of an undersized
be quantified by the Goldschmidt tolerance factor
phase transformations from lower symmetry structures,
with tilted octahedra, to the cubic perovskite structure of
the single lead halide perovskites have proved to be
complex, with tilts of the octahedra away from their
high-symmetry setting locally present even above the
In the lead-free HDPs, this tendency toward octahedral
tilting instabilities remains largely unexplored. While a few
HDPs have been shown to be dynamically unstable at 0 K
and subsequently stabilized by anharmonic phonon-
lying nature of the anharmonicity and its consequences
remain unknown. Furthermore, it was recently experimen-
tally demonstrated that the prototypical lead-free HDP
